Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 06:35PM Jesusisthekey wrote: I had a BMX in May of this year and I did not reconstruct.  I was a side and stomach sleeper and I was worried how I'd deal with it with the drains and such.  I had planned on sleeping on my sofa, which is a recliner type sofa.  I ended up sleeping in my bed.  It wasn't a big deal at all for me.  The first few nights I sort of woke up a lot because I was self conscious of not bumping the drains and stuff.  But then I got smart.  I hadn't been using the Percocet because frankly, I didn't have that much pain.  But I did take a Percocet 15 min. before bed and that did the trick!  I slept like a baby and didn't roll or turn.  When the drains came out I was on my sides and in heaven!  You can do it!  :)  Good luck and God bless.

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 08:47PM Jesusisthekey wrote: Maybe this will help you:  I am 42. Last year I had my annual mammogram and once again for the third year I had stupid calcifications.  Long story short, I had an MRI, Biopsies and lumpectomy and it was atypia with clear margins after the lumpectomy.  I did not have cancer.  I chose to forego the Tamoxifen and get a BMX.  That's right...41 years old completely preventative BMX and did NOT reconstruct.  I have not regretted my decision for one second since (surgery was this past May).  I have great prosthetics (Radiant Impressions) and even my boss just told me two weeks ago that having the surgery was the best decision I could have made because I am a totally different person.  My decision was 1000000% right for me....but not everyone will be able to say that.  My mother was diagnosed with inflammatory breast cancer at age 42 (I am 42 now).  What I saw her go through was indescribable.  Although she was diagnosed as "terminal" she beat it!  But here's the cost of that miracle:  She ended up developing Pick's Disease (horrible type of dementia) and dying in a nursing home 20 years after her victory over cancer.  I believe her taking Tamoxifen for 12 years (yes I said 12) and all of the chemo they gave her is what made her brain appear as Swiss cheese on an MRI.  Look up Pick's Disease sometime.  It's horrid.  However, I was a junior in high school when she was diagnosed with the cancer and I would not have been ready to lose her then!  We had her (or some semblance) of her for 20 extra years!  I am the only solid parent my child has.  My husband left us for another woman and is a bi polar nightmare now.  I knew I had to do whatever it took to be here for my son.  And there was no way I wanted him to have the psychological damage that I developed watching my mom go through chemo hell.  When I look back, it all worked together to make my decision easy.  I didn't realize how much I hated my breasts and how much they terrified me.  I just knew I'd face breast cancer someday and my biggest fear was that it was going to be the deadly kind my mom had.  So I fired the first shot and ended the war before it began.   If you do enough soul searching, you'll find the right decision for your own unique situation.  And don't let pushback from your loved ones influence you.  They are NOT in your shoes!  Some of the family members that all but told me I was nuts are now marveling at the change in me and the "glow" that I exhude.  And...know that God is with you.  You can talk to Him as well.  He will give you the right path to follow if you just listen for his still small voice.  :)

Posts.Content: May 29, 2011 09:38AM Jesusisthekey wrote: I did a double mx prophylactically on May 16.  I was diagnosed with ALH and I'm the daughter of an IBC survivor.  Read my biography for more on why I chose mx.  Anyway, I'm a worrier.  For someone like me, BMX was the answer.  People told me, "Girl, you are so brave!"  I say that brave is also riding it out and seeing if you have a recurrance.  The bottom line is that you need to take a deep look inside and figure out - are you a worrier like me?  Or are you someone who can roll with whatever comes your way?  I wish I was a roller!  :)   There are tons of women who have BC once and never have a recurrance.  You could VERY WELL follow in their footsteps.  The whole thing is about the quality of life you believe you can have as time goes on.  Will you worry or not, etc.  Good luck to you!  I hope all goes perfectly.

Posts.Content: May 17, 2014 11:09AM - edited May 17, 2014 11:09AM by Jesusisthekey I had a bmx in 2011 and did not reconstruct.  I have phantom itching.  In fact, I had its so bad last night it kept me up for over an hour. I've found that the only thing that helps me, and it sounds crazy, is to lightly slap the area that is itching. Scratching it almost makes it worse but slapping it lightly somehow soothes.  I've tried everything from bristle brushes to my facial exfoliator! But the area is Numb and the only thing that breaks through the numbness is tapping it or slapping it. Sounds crazy but it works! I am now considering reconstructing and the only thing that terrifies me is that I will have the same phantom itching as really won't be able to do anything about it.
